message: Some background: I was recently appointed to Django's core development team as a design lead/advocate, with a wide mandate to kick ass and take names.
your thoughts on how best to foster involvement of people from the design sphere
One of my high-level goals is figuring out how to attract designers to Django, and (evil cackle) generally foster more design involvement in Open Source.
What I'm after:
I'm (mis)using the term "design" to refer to a wide spectrum of people whose contributions are not code; this includes usability, UX, UI, IA, and yes, visual designers too.

As a designer/developer hybrid, I hate the false dichotomy between code and pixels, and constantly evangelize the idea that people on both sides of the aisle can learn the fundamentals of the other discipline.
Django benefits from the fact that frontend developers already come into contact with it, so it's not something completely foreign.
There's already a culture of good documentation, and there's good awareness of the value of non-code contributions (doc contributions are highly prized commodities.)
So really, what processes (and tools) have you used which have proven effective? Strategies? I'm open to anything, and would like Django to be a shining example of designer/developer collaboration.
so, at the moment, I'm working on what I'm calling a Social Architecture Initiative for Drupal, code name Prairie (http://groups.drupal.org/prairie-initiative)

so, even if you do start encouraging people to think about design early in the process,  you need to make sure that there are designers who are willing and able to answer the call (and that there's a way to actually get the call out)
yes, but getting that critical mass is the problem. see above re: attrition rate.
well, having looked at both of those options for Drupal, the direction I'm taking is to try to reshape some of the exisitng tools.
and using separate venues would mean a harder time setting that tone again.
here are my current thoughts based on experience with the Drupal community (Roy, who is also here, will have a useful perspective on this too):
in Drupal-land at the moment I'm trying to spread a meme of not trying to attract designers, but rather to get our attrition rate under control.

this will benefit the entire community (hopefully) but making it a more friendly, effective place to contribute - but one of the side effects I'm hoping to achieve is to specifically make it a better place to contribute as a non-coder.
